Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Dynamic Regulation of Protein Quality Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: CAREER: Dynamic Regulation of Protein Quality Control

The three-dimensional structures of proteins determine the roles and functions proteins play within cells. Upon exposure to chemical or mechanical stresses, proteins can misfold, resulting in large changes in three-dimensional structure and loss of protein function. To survive, cells have developed quality control systems that guide misfolded proteins towards pathways that lead to them either being repaired or discarded. This project will determine the biological principles that allow cells to respond to protein misfolding by directing misfolded proteins for destruction. Another goal of this project is to develop techniques that will enable further investigations into how cellular responses to protein misfolding can be controlled. The integrated education objective of this CAREER project is to increase retention of underrepresented minorities in STEM through direct outreach at the high school and undergraduate levels via hands-on research experience and through different outreach programs. The project will integrate research directly into graduate and undergraduate courses with an emphasis on hands-on interpretation of real data and attention to development of visual, verbal and written communication skills.

The requirement for cells to respond to mechanical, thermal or chemical stresses is ubiquitous in biology. The E3 ubiquitin ligase CHIP and the 70 kilodalton heat shock protein, Hsp70, play pivotal roles in the response to cellular stress through the convergence of refolding and degradative pathways. The research will forge connections between dynamics on the picosecond to millisecond timescales and the biological function of chaperoned ubiquitination complexes. The incorporation of gain-of-function mutants developed using insights from high-resolution X-ray crystallographic information will identify the effects of enhancing the CHIP/Hsp70 interaction. The project will redefine how the protein quality control field views the role of interactions between Hsp70 and CHIP in regulating how cells respond to protein misfolding by employing either refolding or degradative approaches. The combination of NMR, SAXS, and EPR with biolayer interferometry will generate advances in the use of hybrid methods for structural biology. A novel real-time ubiquitination assay will demonstrate the utility of biolayer interferometry for rapid and sensitive monitoring of a processive post-translational modification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this CAREER award was to determine how dynamic conformational changes within CHIP (C-terminus of Hsp70 Interacting Protein) and Hsp70 dictate the triage mechanism that directs misfolded proteins for refolding or degradation. The requirement for cells to respond to mechanical, thermal or chemical stresses is ubiquitous in biology. A key component of this response is the convergence of refolding and degradative pathways through the interaction between CHIP and Hsp70. We applied state-of-the art biophysical techniques to forge connections between the structures of CHIP and Hsp70 and the biological function of chaperoned ubiquitination complexes.

Using biolayer interferometry we were able to assess the strength of key interactions within chaperoned ubiquitination complexes by determining the affinity and kinetics of the interaction of the C-terminus of Hsp70 with CHIP. Importantly, we determined these affinities for both native and phosphorylated Hsp70. Paired with our structural data from X-ray crystallography, these results indicate how phosphorylation of Hsp70 alters interactions with CHIP. Building off these studies we examined the role of CHIP phosphorylation at serine 24. Our isothermal titration calorimetry data determined that phosphorylation of CHIP at serine 24 increases the affinity for CHIP. Using our structural data to guide modeling efforts, we propose that CHIP phosphorylation enables interactions with positively charged residues on Hsp70, and that these interactions are not possible when CHIP is not phosphorylated. Our work with collaborators examining the effects in cells indicates that in a biological context, phosphorylation of CHIP at serine 24 is utilized to recruit Hsp70 to CHIP at specific time points within the cell.

The integrated education objective of this CAREER award sought to increase retention of underrepresented minorities in STEM through research-based educational experiences. The PI mentored underrepresented minorities at the undergraduate level via the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP). These opportunities provided for mentorship of students with respect to research, coursework, and career development. Off-campus career development opportunities included a visit to a regional isotope separation facility, providing students with a direct view of how to apply their STEM degrees in an industrial setting after graduation. The PI also provided summer research experiences for three students from Central State University, a local HBCU. This research experience paired Central State University undergraduates with a Miami University graduate student and a Miami University undergraduate student. The students approached research from the CAREER award as a team, providing an opportunity for growth of all students involved including building the skills necessary for interacting within a team. This experiential learning provided opportunities for development of leadership skills for graduate and senior undergraduate students for guiding peers and junior scientists in achieving the research goals. Group discussion sessions and one-on-one mentoring sessions provided additional opportunities for academic advising and career planning to further broaden the impact of these efforts.
